title: Panel Recommends Scrapping Gifted Programs at New York Schools
summary: If approved, the changes would mark major shifts for the nation's largest school district. A diversity panel appointed by Mayor Bill de Blasio has called for New York City to stop using academic criteria to screen applicants for admission to public middle schools, and to phase out elementary gifted-and-talented programs that now require a test.

title: Google Warns Against Blocking 'Cookies' Entirely, Triggering Criticism
summary: Tech company proposes "privacy sandbox" to set new standards after promising in May to let users restrict cookies. After promising to offer tools to let users limit "cookies," tiny files that help internet and advertising companies track users, Alphabet Inc.'s Google suggested it won't go any further, saying in a blog post that blocking cookies entirely could be counterproductive for user privacy.

title: An Oklahoma Opioid Stickup
summary: The $572 million ruling greatly expands product liability tort law.. The ruling Monday by an Oklahoma judge that Johnson & Johnson must pay $572 million for selling opioids will be cheered by everyone who wants a scapegoat for the scourge of addiction. But the ruling could have far larger, and more dangerous, consequences by opening a vast new arena for product-liability suits.

title: Macron's Iran Gambit
summary: He'll have to change Tehran's behavior to salvage the nuclear deal.. Did French President Emmanuel Macron trap President Trump into a potential negotiation with Iranian President Hassan Rouhani? That was a major media preoccupation at the G-7 meetings in France this weekend, but the more important story may have been Israel's weekend bombing of a military site in Syria that was a staging area for Iranian militia.

title: Fire and Fury in the Amazon
summary: The reality is that rich countries are better at protecting the planet.. The photographs are dramatic: Plumes of smoke billow out of the Amazon rain forest, and in the darkness of night the fire casts an eerie glow. "The lungs of the Earth are in flames," says an Instagram post shared by the actor Leonardo DiCaprio. French President Emmanuel Macron warns of a "real ecocide." For a casual news consumer, the pictures and apocalyptic rhetoric may be the end of the story.

title: Death Penalty Sought in Pittsburgh Synagogue Shooting
summary: A rabbi and congregation members have asked for life in prison for suspect. PITTSBURGH-Federal prosecutors said Monday they will seek the death penalty for the man charged with killing 11 people at a synagogue last October.

title: Trade War Puts Ralph Lauren's Recovery at Risk
summary: Analysts cut their forecasts for the fashion company after the latest escalation in U.S.-China trade tensions. Ralph Lauren Corp.'s U.S. turnaround is hanging by a thread, putting its shares at risk of a deeper pullback.

title: Globalfoundries Launches Legal Battle Against Taiwan Semiconductor, Also Targets Manufacturers
summary: In addition to lawsuits, the Santa Clara, Calif.-based chip maker seeks U.S. import ban that could impact device manufacturers. Chip maker Globalfoundries Inc. has launched a legal attack on several fronts against larger rival Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. , including a request that the U.S. government impose an import ban that could hit items such as iPhones, Lenovo laptops and other electronic devices.

title: Charter Schools' Success Is an Illusion
summary: True, their outcomes beat traditional schools. But it's mostly because their students are self-selected.. I teach at James Monroe High, a public school in the Los Angeles Unified School District. More than 80% of my students passed the 2019 Advanced Placement U.S. Government and Politics exam. This far exceeds the national (55%) and California average (52%). All my students are minorities, most are low-income, and few of their parents are educated. Almost all come from immigrant families, some here illegally.

title: Good Riddance to the Flores Decree
summary: The 1997 settlement lets smugglers use children as 'passports' and further enriches drug cartels.. The Trump administration announced last week it will terminate the Flores settlement agreement, a 1997 court decree that has prevented U.S. officials from detaining migrant families and unaccompanied minors for more than 20 days. Media coverage predictably-and inaccurately-warned of "indefinite detention" for families and children caught crossing the southwest border.

title: 'Electable' or Not, Biden Will Lose
summary: Democrats will pick a left-wing nominee once his weaknesses become clear.. The Democratic contest for president might seem impossible to predict, but primaries often follow narrative patterns. I saw one classic story unfold up close in 2012 as senior strategist for Rick Santorum's campaign, which ended in a loss to Mitt Romney. This year Joe Biden is the Democrats' version of Mr. Romney: clinging to his lead despite little enthusiasm and zealous challengers. Democratic voters will soon decide whether they want to nominate Mr. Biden and risk watching his quest for the presidency end the same way.

title: How to Save the Amazon
summary: Natives can't be expected to care about ecology when they're living in poverty.. Fires in the Amazon prompted a world-wide outcry last week. But if you want to save the rainforest, please be realistic. Twenty-three million people live in Brazilian Amazonia, 45% of them below the poverty line. The area includes five of the six poorest states of a poor country, according to the national statistical agency. Starving people don't care about the forest. They consider it a green hell and see forest rangers as enemies.

title: End the Gag Rule, Start the Space Force
summary: The Air Force stalls a key Trump initiative by flagrantly violating academic freedom.. The creation of a Space Force-a proposed new branch of the armed services-is one of the most significant defense discussions in a generation. Everyone from the president and congressmen to late-night comedians have chimed in. Everyone, that is, except for the Air Force's foremost experts on space doctrine, the Space Horizons Task Force.

title: 'The Outlaw Ocean' Review: Wrongs of Passage
summary: A chronicle of dark doings at sea reveals a Hobbesian state of nature available to anyone willing to float a few dozen miles offshore.. The most recent U.S. Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries lists fishermen as the most likely of all Americans to be killed on the job, with about one dead a year for every 1,000 at sea. (Loggers-those softies who work with chain saws and risk being squashed by tree trunks-come in second.) The reasons for this ridiculous mortality rate are obvious: If you work far from medical help, surrounded by icy waters and heavy objects such as boats and nets laden with fish, many things can go wrong, and when they go wrong they often go badly wrong.

title: A Visit With the Dalai Lama
summary: He vows that Chinese law won't govern the conditions of his reincarnation.. Dharamshala, India

title: David Koch's Righteous Profits
summary: Celebrating a businessman whose work in fossil fuels helped improve lives.. David Koch's family hasn't even had time to bury the man yet.

title: Now The 'Stakeholders' Want a Raise
summary: Treating non-owners like owners could be expensive for shareholders.. Well, that didn't take long. Last week this column warned about the consequences after CEOs of many of America's largest public corporations vaguely agreed to serve "stakeholders" who may not actually own any stakes in the companies. Now at least one member of the Business Roundtable is being called upon to put money behind its new commitment to "deliver value" to people other than shareholders.

title: Trump Administration Seeks Power to Enforce Asylum Rule
summary: Lower courts blocked the rule, which requires Central American emigrants to seek refugee status in countries they traveled through. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration on Monday asked the Supreme Court for authority to immediately begin denying asylum to Central Americans who show up at the U.S. border without first seeking refugee status in Mexico or other countries they traveled through.

title: Glassdoor's Operating Chief to Become Its Next CEO
summary: Christian Sutherland-Wong joined Glassdoor in 2015, was promoted to COO in February of last year. Glassdoor Inc.'s head of operations will be the employer-ratings provider's next chief executive, taking the helm from the co-founder with plans on growing the platform and continuing efforts to stop users from gaming it.

title: AT&T Telecom Chief John Donovan to Retire
summary: Veteran executive's departure leaves opening atop wireless business and DirecTV in the U.S.. Senior AT&T Inc. executive John Donovan will retire Oct. 1, leaving a sudden opening atop the company's core business as its leaders confront upheavals in the U.S. media and telecom markets.

title: If a Recession Hits, What's the Game Plan?
summary: Resume Subscription. The Journal is a podcast about money, business and power, hosted by Kate Linebaugh and Ryan Knutson. The Journal is a co-production from Gimlet Media and The Wall Street Journal.

title: Woman Allegedly Tied to Fatal Overdose of Cipriani Dolci Chef Faces Drug Charges
summary: Angelina Barini, a self-described prostitute, was expected to appear in federal court in Brooklyn. A Queens woman allegedly linked to the overdose deaths of three men in New York City hotel rooms, including a chef, was charged Monday with federal drug crimes.

title: Who's Accountable for Student-Loan Scam?
summary: If someone in the private sector had committed such a scam, he would go to jail for fraud.. Your editorial "The Great Student-Loan Scam" (Aug. 21) is quite an eye-opener. If someone in the private sector had committed such a scam, he would go to jail for fraud: Raise money from taxpayers, promise to earn a good return, lend the money to students and then develop programs where the students don't have to repay the full loan. End up declaring bankruptcy. All but the last step have happened. Unfortunately, because this is a government scam, rather than face bankruptcy, the scammers borrow more taxpayer money. This is totally corrupt and without accountability or punishment. The further irony is that some people want to turn our health-care industry over to the government. Heaven help us.

title: Last Chance to Save Freedom in Hong Kong
summary: Where is the international BDS (Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions) movement against China?. I saw a photograph of a young man in Hong Kong, agitating for the right to be free, holding up an American flag amid a chaotic police assault ("Protests in Hong Kong Intensify As Beijing Cites Signs of Terrorism," Page One, Aug. 13). It is a harsh reminder that the U.S.-despite its many faults, embattled as it may be-is a beacon of freedom and inspiration for those who seek it. Are we serving those who seek freedom? Are we living up to our values or are we merely paying lip service to them?

title: PC Hurts Honest Exchanges of Perceptions
summary: Perhaps we will learn to laugh at ourselves again someday.. Regarding Marcos Villatoro's "The Mexican-Salvadoran Antagonism" (op-ed, Aug. 21): In 1981 at the age of 26, I moved cross country to make my fortune in New York City. One evening I attended a party and took a break to smoke a cigarette on the roof of the building. I encountered a young man, also having a smoke on the rooftop. He and I started chatting, and before long he was ranting about the Guatemalans and the Hondurans and the Nicaraguans, whom he considered to be the scum of the earth, put here only to torment the noble Salvadorans, like himself. After listening for a while, I interrupted him and said: "Well, I'm from California. You guys are all Mexicans to me." There was a tense moment when I thought he might toss me off the roof, but then he smiled and we became two human beings laughing at ourselves together. I find it sad that I can no longer tell this very human story without fear of reprisal. Perhaps we will learn to laugh at ourselves again someday.

title: It Is Too Early for Pharma Investors to Cheer Opioid Verdict
summary: Johnson & Johnson ruling is a relief for shareholders, but other drug makers and distributors likely won't benefit. Hold the celebration: The opioid litigation cloud hanging over drug stocks won't clear up soon.

title: Big Tech Shares Lose Their Luster
summary: FAANG shares, once darlings of the tech sector, have struggled to reclaim their highs. The FAANG trade is losing its bite.

title: Good Exercise, in This Case Boxing, Helped Dementia
summary: I have a patient who was deteriorating from Parkinson's disease. His muscle power was weak and his mental abilities were declining. He took up boxing. The results were amazing.. I usually see geriatric patients in my practice, and many have symptoms of early dementia ("Your Health: Dancing to Fight Dementia," Life & Arts, Aug. 20). I have a patient who was deteriorating from Parkinson's disease. His muscle power was weak and his mental abilities were declining. He took up boxing. The results were amazing. His muscle power and flexibility increased. His gait improved, and he outperformed others in his age group. The camaraderie in boxing increased his mental acuity and reasoning abilities.

title: The Left Needs to Moderate Its Presentation to Win
summary: Enlightened Democratic intellectuals, like Jonathan Haidt and Mark Lilla, have warned of the dangers stemming from overt political correctness, identity politics and the "Oppression Olympics.". Ioannis Gatsiounis is a progressive truly "woke" to the dangers of sententious liberalism ("We Liberals Need Self-Criticism," op-ed, Aug. 22). Enlightened Democratic intellectuals, like Jonathan Haidt and Mark Lilla, have warned of the dangers stemming from overt political correctness, identity politics and the "Oppression Olympics." President Obama additionally warned of the election risk of a liberal "circular firing squad," which appears to be forming.

summary: The superstar's new album has plenty that will please her fans as well as songs for those who are new to her music..

title: Treasury Yields Rebound on Trump's China Comments
summary: Possibility of a de-escalation of trade tensions with China comforts investors. U.S. government-bond yields whipsawed Monday, dropping early in the session before recovering after comments by President Trump about a possible easing in trade tensions with China.

title: DEA Takes Step Toward Expanding Marijuana Research
summary: After delay under Attorney General Jeff Sessions, DEA will begin advancing applications to study health effects; pot advocate says 'foot-dragging will continue'.

title: Buyback Season Isn't Over for All Big Tech Firms
summary: Share repurchases by major companies have been cooling, but tech giants like Google and Facebook have good reason to keep buying. While some big tech companies are cooling their buyback activity, others are just getting started.

title: Newark Is Borrowing $120 Million to Replace Lead Pipes
summary: The New Jersey city wants clean drinking water sooner rather than later and will use funds to speed up work. Newark, N.J., will use a $120 million loan to speed up replacement of its lead water pipes and reduce elevated levels of lead in drinking water, state and local officials said.

title: Facebook Wins Appeal Against German Data-Collection Ban
summary: Court reverses antitrust authority's ruling that social-media giant abused its dominance. BERLIN- Facebook Inc. won an appeal to a German antitrust edict regarding how it collects user data across its platforms, including Instagram and WhatsApp, an initial victory for the social-media giant as it faces wide regulatory scrutiny in Europe and the U.S.

title: Lyft Shares Rally on Hopes Price Increases Will Drive Profit
summary: Guggenheim analysts predict company will turn a profit sooner than expected. Shares of ride-hailing app Lyft Inc. got a boost Monday after analysts predicted the company could be profitable sooner than expected.

title: U.S. Companies Looking for More Experience in Their Finance Chiefs
summary: The average age of CFOs has increased significantly this year, according to Crist | Kolder Associates. Companies picking new finance chiefs of late appear to be telegraphing a message in their choices: Playtime is over. This is a job for grown-ups.

title: U.S. Stocks Gain as Trump Says China Wants a Deal
summary: President says China asked to 'get back to the table' for trade talks; bond yields rise. U.S. stocks climbed Monday after President Trump said China wants to reach a trade agreement, signaling a potential de-escalation in tensions between the world's two largest economies.

title: Telling the Truth About Tennis
summary: Noah Rubin's Instagram series "Behind the Racquet" chronicles the humble real world outside the Top 10. Stroll the bright, well-maintained grounds of the U.S. Open, a $20 vodka lemonade in hand, and it all appears so glamorous: the world's best tennis players, some of them mega-millionaires and household names (Roger! Serena! Rafa!), cheered by thousands of fans from around the world.

title: U.K.'s Johnson More Optimistic About Avoiding No-Deal Brexit
summary: Officials say British PM has made progress, but still needs to win over key EU officials-and Ireland. BIARRITZ, France-British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said he felt more optimistic about achieving a Brexit deal and not crashing out of the European Union after spending most of the past week touring Europe, meeting leaders and pitching his proposals to alter terms of the divorce agreement.

summary: The first male African-American pro, Robert Ryland remains active teaching as he approaches his 100th birthday. Robert Ryland is a tennis lifer.

summary: Long-term subscriptions could be answer to app churn, but few can get away with it. Walt Disney is already deploying some big guns in the coming streaming war-its fans.

title: Indian Sugar Glut Pushes Prices Close to Decade Lows
summary: New Delhi is expected to renew subsidy program that will boost exports from the world's biggest sugar producer. August has been a bitter month for sugar traders as a potential surfeit of Indian exports, the strong dollar and a slowing world economy combined to push prices toward their lowest level in a decade.

title: Wisconsin Congressman Sean Duffy to Resign
summary: Citing family concerns, the five-term congressman said he will leave office on Sept. 23. Rep. Sean Duffy is resigning from Congress next month, the Wisconsin Republican announced.

title: Dollar-Store Chains to Pay $1.2 Million Over Expired-Product Claims
summary: Dollar Tree, Family Dollar and Dollar General stores sold expired medicine, New York attorney general says. Three dollar-store chains reached a collective $1.2 million settlement with the New York attorney general's office after undercover investigators found expired over-the-counter drugs and obsolete motor oil on store shelves in the state.

title: Israeli Teenager Killed in West Bank Bombing
summary: Militant group Hamas praised the attack but didn't take responsibility for it. TEL AVIV-An Israeli teenager was killed Friday in a bombing at a natural spring near a central West Bank settlement, an attack that raises already high tensions between Israelis and Palestinians ahead of Israeli elections next month.

title: Kraft Heinz Replaces Finance Chief
summary: Paulo Basilio to succeed David Knopf as the company attempts to move past such challenges as accounting errors, slowing sales. Kraft Heinz Co. replaced its chief financial officer with his predecessor after accounting errors and weak sales at the food giant have undermined the value of its brands and shares.

summary: Judiciary Committee continues with its probe of President Trump's conduct related to special counsel Mueller's investigation. The House Judiciary Committee has subpoenaed former White House staff secretary Rob Porter as part of its investigation into whether President Trump obstructed justice.

summary: Some in Congress question whether deal would secure U.S. against another 9/11, as critics say elections could hinder talks on country's political future. summary: The comedian and actress talks about battling $25,000 in credit-card debt-and persevering in the face of limits others put on her. When comedian and actress Maysoon Zayid was in college, she racked up about $25,000 in credit-card debt.

title: Republican Party Chooses Ex-NYPD Officer to Run for Queens District Attorney
summary: Joe Murray, a Democrat who supports President Trump, was disciplined after breaking another officer's jaw. The Queens Republican Party has selected a police officer turned lawyer as its candidate for district attorney in the run-up to this fall's contest for the borough's top prosecutor.

title: Why We Should Teach Kids to Call the Robot 'It'
summary: As a new generation grows up surrounded by artificial intelligence, researchers find education as early as preschool can help avoid confusion about robots' role. If you want your preschooler to grow up with a healthy attitude toward artificial intelligence, here's a tip: Don't call that cute talking robot "he" or "she."

title: Carlos Ghosn Ran a Tech Fund-Using Millions From an Executive at a Nissan Partner
summary: Resume Subscription. Nissan Motor Co. boss Carlos Ghosn built a parallel business as an investor in Silicon Valley with his son, using millions of dollars he received from an executive at a Nissan business partner in Oman.

title: 'Complete Woody Herman Decca, Mars, MGM Sessions (1943-54)' Review: A Decade of Many Changes
summary: A new collection reveals Herman's genius as a bandleader, musician, coach and more, as well as the evolving sound of the group he headed.. It's March 25, 1946, and you've come to Carnegie Hall to hear the most exciting jazz orchestra then playing, Woody Herman and His Orchestra-known to fans and followers as "The Thundering Herd." Herman starts the concert agreeably enough with "Caldonia," the Louis Jordan R&B classic that was also a hit for him, and then he launches into "Bijou," the darndest thing you've ever heard. It begins with a polyrhythmic pattern like none ever known previously in jazz, as expressed by an unusual combination of vibes, bass and percussion; this is immediately followed by another off-kilter staccato rhythmic passage, this one played mostly by the brass.

title: Trump Eyes Florida Resort as G-7 Venue
summary: The president used a meeting with Germany's Angela Merkel to plug the Trump National Doral resort as a likely location for next year's summit. BIARRITZ, France-President Trump is eyeing a new showcase for his hotel business: next year's Group of Seven summit.

title: Egypt's Sisi: Warm U.S. Embrace, Harsh Human-Rights Record
summary: Detention of Americans is a small part of a much broader and apparently widening crackdown by Sisi's government on dissent. Here's a foreign-policy quiz for those watching this week's Group of Seven meeting of world leaders in France: Which Middle Eastern country holds more American citizens in prison? Is it Egypt, the close American ally whose leader had a friendly meeting with President Trump Monday, or Iran, the nation under severe economic sanctions whose foreign minister was shunned by American officials in France?

summary: Only 5% of U.S. donations involve a transfer from a live donor, even though survival rates are better. He is a 28-year-old police officer in North Carolina.

Ron Meyer, the vice chairman of NBCUniversal, has sold his Malibu beach house for about $100 million in one of the largest residential transactions ever completed in California, according to a person familiar with the deal.

title: Why Millennials Love Cacti
summary: From your Instagram feed to your local clothing store, plants are inescapable. Why this trend just keeps on growing. If you have both a green thumb and a healthy surplus of greenbacks, the online fashion retailer Mr Porter will gladly sell you a Japanese-made "gardening set" for $995. Comprising a canvas tote bag and steel utensils that seem much too delicate to actually prune a ficus, the package is one of several signs that fashion is actively cultivating an interest in gardening. During this June's Milan Fashion Week, I watched a model strut down the Fendi runway clutching watering cans whose lavish leather-wrapped spouts suggest rather precious landscaping. In Paris a week later, Milan-based label Jil Sander issued an invitation to its show that included three sooty seed balls, foreshadowing a runway that was lined in potted green shoots.

title: Harvey Weinstein Indicted for Third Time
summary: Decision clears way for actress to testify against him in his criminal trial, which was delayed until January. Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein was indicted for a third time, just two weeks before his criminal trial had been set to begin, clearing the way for an additional accuser to testify against him.

title: Private Jets Ferried Relatives of NRA Chief Executive
summary: Itineraries, other records show NRA paid for flights to and from Nebraska, where niece and her daughter live. The National Rifle Association paid for private jets to fly to and from central Nebraska to ferry relatives of the group's chief executive, Wayne LaPierre, according to travel itineraries, emails and aviation records reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Amgen Shows Price Is Still Right for Blockbuster Drug Deals

title: How Téa Obreht Beat the Second Novel Slump
summary: Author Téa Obreht built on the success of her smash debut novel, 'The Tiger's Wife,' with her expansive new western, 'Inland'. It's difficult not to feel thirsty while reading Inland, Téa Obreht's expansive second novel following The Tigers's Wife, her National Book Award-nominated 2011 debut. If The Tiger's Wife explores the mythology of a Balkan country, seemingly based on the 33-year-old author's birthplace of Belgrade in the former Yugoslavia, then Inland unravels the legends and lore of her current homeland, the United States. Obreht reimagines the American western with a combination of urgency and dread in Inland, set in the oppressive heat and dust of the Arizona Territory in 1893.

title: Shares of Pitney Bowes Gain on Sale of Software Business

summary: The 15-year-old American won three rounds at Wimbledon. Fans should savor every moment in New York, as age-restriction rules could limit her play before she turns 18.. title: Investigation of New York City Shelter Operator Grows
summary: Since 2010 the nonprofit Acacia Network Housing has received more than $1 billion in contracts from the city's Department of Homeless Services to run shelters. New York City officials have expanded their investigation into a top nonprofit contractor that operates homeless shelters after discovering it has alleged undisclosed ties to a second for-profit company.

title: Tension Between Trump, World Leaders Takes Spotlight at G-7 Summit
summary: The U.S. president doubled down on a trade war with China and Macron met with Iran's foreign minister on the sidelines. BIARRITZ, France-President Trump clashed with world leaders over the U.S. trade war with China and a host of foreign-policy issues at a Group of Seven summit that showed his isolation on the world stage.
